data: We present the final report from a series of precision measurements of the muon anomalous magnetic moment, a μ=(g− 2)/2. The details of the experimental method, apparatus, data taking, and analysis are summarized. Data obtained at Brookhaven National Laboratory, using nearly equal samples of positive and negative muons, were used to deduce a μ (Expt)= 11659208.0 (5.4)(3.3)× 10− 10, where the statistical and systematic uncertainties are given, respectively. The combined uncertainty of 0.54 ppm represents a 14-fold improvement compared to previous measurements at CERN. The standard model value for a μ includes contributions from virtual QED, weak, and hadronic processes. While the QED processes account for most of the anomaly, the largest theoretical uncertainty,≈ 0.55 ppm, is associated with first-order hadronic vacuum polarization. Present standard model evaluations, based on e+ e …
Final report of the E821 muon anomalous magnetic moment measurement at BNL

Gerald W Bennett and B Bousquet and HN Brown and G Bunce and RM Carey and P Cushman and GT Danby and PT Debevec and M Deile and H Deng and W Deninger and SK Dhawan and VP Druzhinin and L Duong and E Efstathiadis and FJM Farley and GV Fedotovich and S Giron and FE Gray and D Grigoriev and M Grosse-Perdekamp and A Grossmann and MF Hare and DW Hertzog and X Huang and VW Hughes and M Iwasaki and K Jungmann and D Kawall and M Kawamura and BI Khazin and J Kindem and F Krienen and I Kronkvist and A Lam and R Larsen and YY Lee and I Logashenko and R McNabb and W Meng and J Mi and JP Miller and Y Mizumachi and WM Morse and D Nikas and CJG Onderwater and Y Orlov and CS Özben and JM Paley and Q Peng and CC Polly and J Pretz and R Prigl and G Zu Putlitz and T Qian and SI Redin and O Rind and BL Roberts and N Ryskulov and S Sedykh and Yannis K Semertzidis and P Shagin and Yu M Shatunov and EP Sichtermann and E Solodov and M Sossong and A Steinmetz and LR Sulak and C Timmermans and A Trofimov and D Urner and P Von Walter and D Warburton and D Winn and A Yamamoto and D Zimmerman and Muon g-2 Collaboration

A precise measurement of the anomalous g value, a μ=(g− 2)/2, for the positive muon has been made at the Brookhaven Alternating Gradient Synchrotron. The result a μ+= 11 659 202 (14)(6)× 10− 10 (1.3 ppm) is in good agreement with previous measurements and has an error one third that of the combined previous data. The current theoretical value from the standard model is a μ (SM)= 11 659 159.6 (6.7)× 10− 10 (0.57 ppm) and a μ (exp)− a μ (SM)= 43 (16)× 10− 10 in which a μ (exp) is the world average experimental value.
Precise measurement of the positive muon anomalous magnetic moment

HN Brown and G Bunce and RM Carey and P Cushman and GT Danby and PT Debevec and M Deile and H Deng and W Deninger and SK Dhawan and VP Druzhinin and L Duong and E Efstathiadis and FJM Farley and GV Fedotovich and S Giron and F Gray and D Grigoriev and M Grosse-Perdekamp and A Grossmann and MF Hare and DW Hertzog and VW Hughes and M Iwasaki and K Jungmann and D Kawall and M Kawamura and BI Khazin and J Kindem and F Krienen and I Kronkvist and R Larsen and YY Lee and I Logashenko and R McNabb and W Meng and J Mi and JP Miller and WM Morse and D Nikas and CJG Onderwater and Y Orlov and CS Özben and JM Paley and C Polly and J Pretz and R Prigl and G Zu Putlitz and SI Redin and O Rind and BL Roberts and N Ryskulov and S Sedykh and Yannis K Semertzidis and Yu M Shatunov and EP Sichtermann and E Solodov and M Sossong and A Steinmetz and LR Sulak and C Timmermans and A Trofimov and D Urner and P Von Walter and D Warburton and D Winn and A Yamamoto and D Zimmerman

The anomalous magnetic moment of the negative muon has been measured to a precision of 0.7 ppm (ppm) at the Brookhaven Alternating Gradient Synchrotron. This result is based on data collected in 2001, and is over an order of magnitude more precise than the previous measurement for the negative muon. The result a μ−= 11 659 214 (8)(3)× 10− 10 (0.7 ppm), where the first uncertainty is statistical and the second is systematic, is consistent with previous measurements of the anomaly for the positive and the negative muon. The average of the measurements of the muon anomaly is a μ (exp)= 11 659 208 (6)× 10− 10 (0.5 ppm).
Measurement of the negative muon anomalous magnetic moment to 0.7 ppm

GW Bennett and B Bousquet and HN Brown and G Bunce and RM Carey and P Cushman and GT Danby and PT Debevec and M Deile and H Deng and SK Dhawan and VP Druzhinin and L Duong and FJM Farley and GV Fedotovich and FE Gray and D Grigoriev and M Grosse-Perdekamp and A Grossmann and MF Hare and DW Hertzog and X Huang and VW Hughes and M Iwasaki and K Jungmann and D Kawall and BI Khazin and F Krienen and I Kronkvist and A Lam and R Larsen and YY Lee and I Logashenko and R McNabb and W Meng and JP Miller and WM Morse and D Nikas and CJG Onderwater and Y Orlov and CS Özben and JM Paley and Q Peng and CC Polly and J Pretz and R Prigl and G Zu Putlitz and T Qian and SI Redin and O Rind and BL Roberts and N Ryskulov and Yannis K Semertzidis and P Shagin and Yu M Shatunov and EP Sichtermann and E Solodov and M Sossong and LR Sulak and A Trofimov and P Von Walter and A Yamamoto and Muon (g-2) Collaboration

A higher precision measurement of the anomalous g value, a μ=(g− 2)/2, for the positive muon has been made at the Brookhaven Alternating Gradient Synchrotron, based on data collected in the year 2000. The result a μ+= 11 659 204 (7)(5)× 10− 10 (0.7 ppm) is in good agreement with previous measurements and has an error about one-half that of the combined previous data. The present world average experimental value is a μ (e x p t)= 11 659 203 (8)× 10− 10 (0.7 ppm).
Measurement of the positive muon anomalous magnetic moment to 0.7 ppm

GW Bennett and B Bousquet and HN Brown and G Bunce and RM Carey and P Cushman and GT Danby and PT Debevec and M Deile and H Deng and W Deninger and SK Dhawan and VP Druzhinin and L Duong and E Efstathiadis and FJM Farley and GV Fedotovich and S Giron and FE Gray and D Grigoriev and M Grosse-Perdekamp and A Grossmann and MF Hare and DW Hertzog and X Huang and VW Hughes and M Iwasaki and K Jungmann and D Kawall and BI Khazin and J Kindem and F Krienen and I Kronkvist and A Lam and R Larsen and YY Lee and I Logashenko and R McNabb and W Meng and J Mi and JP Miller and WM Morse and D Nikas and CJG Onderwater and Y Orlov and CS Özben and JM Paley and Q Peng and CC Polly and J Pretz and R Prigl and G Zu Putlitz and T Qian and SI Redin and O Rind and BL Roberts and N Ryskulov and P Shagin and Yannis K Semertzidis and Yu M Shatunov and EP Sichtermann and E Solodov and M Sossong and A Steinmetz and LR Sulak and A Trofimov and D Urner and P Von Walter and D Warburton and A Yamamoto and Muon (g-2) Collaboration

Hypernuclear lifetime and partial decay-rate measurements made at the Brookhaven National Laboratory Alternating Gradient Synchrotron are reported for He Λ 5 and C Λ 12. The mesonic and nonmesonic decays are compared to existing weak-interaction calculations. In particular, the nonmesonic reaction ΛN→ NN is discussed as an example of a nonleptonic weak process for which calculations have been reported using various effective weak Hamiltonians.
Nonleptonic weak decay of He Λ 5 and C Λ 12

JJ Szymanski and PD Barnes and GE Diebold and RA Eisenstein and GB Franklin and R Grace and DW Hertzog and CJ Maher and BP Quinn and R Rieder and J Seydoux and WR Wharton and S Bart and RE Chrien and P Pile and R Sutter and Y Xu and R Hackenburg and EV Hungerford and T Kishimoto and LG Tang and B Bassalleck and RL Stearns

Three independent searches for an electric dipole moment (EDM) of the positive and negative muons have been performed, using spin precession data from the muon g− 2 storage ring at Brookhaven National Laboratory. Details on the experimental apparatus and the three analyses are presented. Since the individual results on the positive and negative muons, as well as the combined result, d μ=(0.0±0.9)× 10− 19 e cm, are all consistent with zero, we set a new muon EDM limit,| d μ|< 1.8× 10− 19 e cm (95% CL). This represents a factor of 5 improvement over the previous best limit on the muon EDM.
Improved limit on the muon electric dipole moment

Final report of the E821 muon anomalous magnetic moment measurement at BNL

RM Carey and E Efstathiadis and MF Hare and X Huang and F Krienen and A Lam and I Logashenko and JP Miller and JM Paley and Q Peng and O Rind and BL Roberts and LR Sulak and A Trofimov and GW Bennett and HN Brown and G Bunce and GT Danby and R Larsen and YY Lee and W Meng and J Mi and WM Morse and D Nikas and CS Özben and R Prigl and YK Semertzidis and D Warburton and VP Druzhinin and GV Fedotovich and D Grigoriev and BI Khazin and SI Redin and N Ryskulov and Yu M Shatunov and E Solodov and Y Orlov and D Winn and K Jungmann and CJG Onderwater and A Grossmann and G Zu Putlitz and P Von Walter and PT Debevec and W Deninger and FE Gray and DW Hertzog and R McNabb and CC Polly and S Sedykh and M Sossong and D Urner and A Yamamoto and B Bousquet and P Cushman and L Duong and S Giron and J Kindem and I Kronkvist and T Qian and P Shagin and C Timmermans and D Zimmerman and Y Mizumachi and M Iwasaki and M Kawamura and M Deile and H Deng and SK Dhawan and FJM Farley and M Grosse-Perdekamp and VW Hughes and D Kawall and J Pretz and EP Sichtermann and A Steinmetz

The muon anomalous magnetic moment has been measured in a new experiment at Brookhaven. Polarized muons were stored in a superferric ring, and the angular frequency difference, ω a, between the spin precession and orbital frequencies was determined by measuring the time distribution of high-energy decay positrons. The ratio R of ω a to the Larmor precession frequency of free protons, ω p, in the storage-ring magnetic field was measured. We find R= 3.707 220 (48)× 10− 3. With μ μ/μ p= 3.183 345 47 (47) this gives a μ+= 1 165 925 (15)× 10− 9 (±13 ppm), in good agreement with the previous CERN measurements for μ+ and μ− and of approximately the same precision.
New measurement of the anomalous magnetic moment of the positive muon

Robert M Carey and W Earle and E Efstathiadis and MF Hare and ES Hazen and BJ Hughes and F Krienen and JP Miller and V Monich and J Ouyang and O Rind and BL Roberts and LR Sulak and A Trofimov and G Varner and WA Worstell and E Benedict and I Logashenko and J Benante and HN Brown and G Bunce and J Cullen and GT Danby and J Geller and H Hseuh and JW Jackson and L Jia and S Kochis and R Larsen and YY Lee and M Mapes and W Meng and WM Morse and C Pai and C Pearson and I Polk and R Prigl and S Rankowitz and J Sandberg and Yannis K Semertzidis and R Shutt and L Snydstrup and A Soukas and A Stillman and T Tallerico and M Tanaka and F Toldo and D von Lintig and D Warburton and K Woodle and A Chertovskikh and VP Druzhinin and GV Fedotovich and DN Grigorev and VB Golubev and BI Khazin and A Maksimov and Yu Merzliakov and N Ryskulov and S Serednyakov and Yu M Shatunov and E Solodov and Y Orlov and D Winn and A Grossmann and J Gerhaeuser and K Jungmann and P von Walter and G Zu Putlitz and B Bunker and W Deninger and PT Debevec and DW Hertzog and TD Jones and C Polly and S Sedykh and D Urner and U Haeberlen and K Endo and H Hirabayashi and S Kurokawa and A Yamamoto and MA Green and P Cushman and J Kindem and L Duong and S Giron and R McNabb and D Miller and C Timmermans and D Zimmerman and Y Mizumachi and M Iwasaki and HE Ahn and H Deng and SK Dhawan and A Disco and FJM Farley and X Fei and M Grosse-Perdekamp and VW Hughes and D Kawall and SI Redin and A Steinmetz

A new measurement of the positive muon’s anomalous magnetic moment has been made at the Brookhaven Alternating Gradient Synchrotron using the direct injection of polarized muons into the superferric storage ring. The angular frequency difference ω a between the angular spin precession frequency ω s and the angular orbital frequency ω c is measured as well as the free proton NMR frequency ω p. These determine R= ω a/ω p= 3.707 201 (19)× 10− 3. With μ μ/μ p= 3.183 345 39 (10) this gives a μ+= 11 659 191 (59)× 10− 10 (±5 ppm), in good agreement with the previous CERN and BNL measurements for μ+ and μ−, and with the standard model prediction.
Improved measurement of the positive muon anomalous magnetic moment

HN Brown and G Bunce and RM Carey and P Cushman and GT Danby and PT Debevec and H Deng and W Deninger and SK Dhawan and VP Druzhinin and L Duong and W Earle and E Efstathiadis and GV Fedotovich and FJM Farley and S Giron and F Gray and M Grosse-Perdekamp and A Grossmann and U Haeberlen and MF Hare and ES Hazen and DW Hertzog and VW Hughes and M Iwasaki and K Jungmann and D Kawall and M Kawamura and BI Khazin and J Kindem and F Krienen and I Kronkvist and R Larsen and YY Lee and I Logashenko and R McNabb and W Meng and J Mi and JP Miller and WM Morse and CJG Onderwater and Y Orlov and C Özben and C Polly and C Pai and JM Paley and J Pretz and R Prigl and G Zu Putlitz and SI Redin and O Rind and BL Roberts and N Ryskulov and S Sedykh and Yannis K Semertzidis and Yu M Shatunov and E Solodov and M Sossong and A Steinmetz and LR Sulak and C Timmermans and A Trofimov and D Urner and P Von Walter and D Warburton and D Winn and A Yamamoto and D Zimmerman and Muon (g-2) Collaboration

We report a measurement of the positive muon lifetime to a precision of 1.0 ppm; it is the most precise particle lifetime ever measured. The experiment used a time-structured, low-energy muon beam and a segmented plastic scintillator array to record more than 2× 10 12 decays. Two different stopping target configurations were employed in independent data-taking periods. The combined results give τ μ+(MuLan)= 2 196 980.3 (2.2) ps, more than 15 times as precise as any previous experiment. The muon lifetime gives the most precise value for the Fermi constant: G F (MuLan)= 1.166 378 8 (7)× 10− 5 GeV− 2 (0.6 ppm). It is also used to extract the μ− p singlet capture rate, which determines the proton’s weak induced pseudoscalar coupling g P.
Measurement of the positive muon lifetime and determination of the Fermi constant to part-per-million precision

DM Webber and V Tishchenko and Q Peng and S Battu and RM Carey and DB Chitwood and J Crnkovic and PT Debevec and S Dhamija and W Earle and A Gafarov and K Giovanetti and TP Gorringe and FE Gray and Z Hartwig and DW Hertzog and B Johnson and P Kammel and B Kiburg and S Kizilgul and J Kunkle and B Lauss and I Logashenko and KR Lynch and R McNabb and JP Miller and F Mulhauser and CJG Onderwater and J Phillips and S Rath and BL Roberts and P Winter and B Wolfe and MuLan Collaboration
